summary_reasoning: The report demonstrates high originality through multiple company-specific syntheses and a well-defined thesis regarding American Express's growth trajectory. The analyst provides a clear, testable thesis on NII deceleration, linking the completion of a specific strategic shift (younger demographic acquisition) to a slowdown from a 26% CAGR to mid-single digits. Key insights include the quantification of the 'product refresh' strategy, noting that average fees per card rose from $75 to $105 over three years, and the specific mechanism of the SME moat, which leverages closed-loop data to offer larger spending limits than peers. Furthermore, the report adds value by translating macro events, such as the Fed stress tests, into specific, quantified impacts on the coverage group's capital buffers, estimating a 40-65 bps decline. These insights go beyond boilerplate descriptions of 'brand' or 'scale,' offering decision-relevant data points and causal links. The valuation section is supported by these novel drivers, specifically the interplay between membership reward expenses and discount revenue growth to project a stable 22% operating margin through 2029.

insights_classified.text: We estimate that the banks in our coverage will see their stress capital buffers decline by about 40 basis points on average... or 65 basis points otherwise.

Shift toward a younger cardholder base and more lending features... we expect this growth to decelerate significantly in 2025 and on, as it was driven by specific strategic and product shifts that have run their course.
American Express offers its SME cardholders revolving debt with no preset spending limit... major draw is that they have line sizes that are several times larger [than competitors].
Major force behind the rapid growth is American Express’ product refreshes... average fee per card at $105 in the third quarter of 2024, up from $75 three years ago.
We expect American Express' operating margin to be stable over time, ending 2029 at 22%, effectively unchanged from 2024 [due to reward expense growth].
